Bachelor of Science in Computer Engineering

TOUCHGUIDANCE: ENHANCING ACCESSIBILITY WITH AN ARDUINO-BASED SMART CANE DEVICE FOR VISUALLY IMPAIRED IN SAN PABLO CITY OF LAGUNA

Engr. Jian Jayne O. Muñoz

2024

Components Schematic Diagram Source Code Developer

Trivia!

According to Art Walking Sticks (2023), Walking sticks were widely used by both men and women in ancient Egypt. They frequently had elaborate carvings and ornamentation and were constructed of wood. High-ranking officials and members of the royal family frequently carried walking sticks, which were regarded as a sign of authority and power. Important papers or priceless items were kept in secret sections built inside some sticks.

Did you know?

Arduino Uno

Arduino (/ɑːrˈdwiːnoʊ/) is an Italian open-source hardware and software company, project, and user community that designs and manufactures single-board microcontrollers and microcontroller kits for building digital devices. Its software is released under the GNU Lesser General Public License (LGPL) or the GNU General Public License (GPL), which allows anybody to manufacture Arduino boards and distribute the software. Its hardware goods are licensed under a CC BY-SA license. Arduino boards can be purchased commercially from approved distributors or the official website

Numerous microprocessors and controllers are used in Arduino board designs. Various extension boards (also known as "shields"), breadboards (for prototyping), and other circuits can be interfaced with the boards' sets of digital and analog input/output (I/O) pins. In addition to being utilized for program loading, the boards have serial communications interfaces, such as Universal Serial Bus (USB) on certain variants. In addition to using conventional compiler toolchains, the Arduino project offers an integrated development environment (IDE) and a command line tool created in Go. The microcontrollers can be programmed using the C and C++ programming languages (Embedded C) and a standard API, also known as the Arduino Programming Language, which is inspired by the Processing language and used with a modified version of the Processing IDE.

Need help choosing the right Arduino?

Introduction

Courtesy: Resources for the Blind, Inc. Philippines, May 2023

Figure 1 Blind Community

In the realm of technological innovation, the quest for inclusive solutions has paved the way for groundbreaking advancements aimed at improving the lives of individuals with diverse needs. Among those who face unique challenges in their daily lives, the visually impaired community stands out, grappling with obstacles that hinder their mobility and independence (Wang Y, 2019). Addressing this pressing issue, our proposed device is an automated one, which helps a visually impaired person detect obstacles either through beeps or vibrations allowing him to walk confidently and smartly even in a crowded area. According to the World Health Organization (WHO), it is estimated that approximately 1.3 billion people live with some form of vision impairment. Thus, we have come up with a solution of this innovation using multidisciplinary subjects which is reliable and cost-effective (Das et al., 2019).

Objectives of the Project

General Objective:
The project aims to support the visually impaired in San Pablo City of Laguna using Arduino-Based SmartCane.

Specific objectives:
Specifically, the project aims to:

1. Design and develop a device that perform the following:
a. Detecting the distance of objects ahead through the use of Ultrasonic Sensor HC-SR04 in order to be aware of any objects in front;
b. Vibrating on the hand of the smart cane to have an indication that there is an object ahead of the distance of 0.034cm;
c. Emitting sound using alarm buzzer module when 0.034cm distance detected, therefore that the user's surroundings knows that there is an object in front;

2. Prepare a deployment plan that can be used in San Pablo City of Laguna.

Design of the Project

Note: Feel free to hover over each component to see its details.

Figure 2 Smart Cane 3D Model

The smart cane consists of several components, including an Arduino microcontroller, ultrasonic sensors, a vibration motor, and a speaker. The ultrasonic sensors are used to detect obstacles in the user's path and send signals to the Arduino, which then activates the vibration motor to alert the user. The speaker is used to provide auditory cues, such as directions or warnings of nearby obstacles. This feature is particularly useful for individuals who are unfamiliar with their surroundings particularly who are visually impaired. The design of the smart cane is also focused on safety and durability. The device is lightweight and compact, making it easy to carry and maneuver. It is also designed to withstand the wear and tear of daily use, with a sturdy construction and waterproof casing.

Flowchart

Figure 3 Flowchart

The smart cane operates through a carefully structured sequence, beginning with its initialization upon activation. If the device responds negatively during this phase, indicating a failure to initialize correctly, a predefined process is triggered to send the smart cane back for further assessment or repair. Conversely, in the case of a positive response, the cane seamlessly moves through the next stages of functionality. It employs an ultrasonic sensor to detect nearby objects, and upon identifying an object at a distance of 0.034 units, a simultaneous activation of the vibration motor and alarm buzzer ensues, providing the user with a clear indication of the proximity of an obstacle. Additionally, the device is designed for continuous operation, as a straightforward loop restarts the operating system, ensuring reliability in assisting individuals with visual impairments.

In summary, the smart cane's systematic approach integrates both positive and negative responses, offering users an effective and reliable tool for navigating their surroundings. The combination of advanced sensor technology, distance assessment, and immediate feedback mechanisms contributes to a seamless and dependable user experience, promoting safety and independence for individuals with visual impairments.

Circuit Diagram

Make sure that the wires/pins are connected and correct.

Figure 4 Pin Layout

Figure 5 Schematic Diagram

The circuit diagram consists of several components that work together to convert the ultrasonic signals into digital data that can be read by the Arduino board. The ultrasonic sensor itself is an HC-SR04 module, which has four pins: VCC (5V), GND (ground), Trigger (pin 2), and Echo (pin 3). The Trigger pin is connected to digital pin 2 of the Arduino board, and it is used to send a short pulse to initiate the ultrasonic measurement. The Echo pin is connected to digital pin 3 of the Arduino board, and it receives the reflected ultrasonic signal from the object.

Source Code

Make it sure that you have a Arduino IDE to run this code.

// Define pin numbers
const int trigPin = 2;
const int echoPin = 3;
const int buzzerPin = 4;
const int motorPin = 5;
                
// Define threshold distance for detection
const int detectionThreshold = 30; 
// Adjust the value based on your needs
                
void setup() {
  Serial.begin(9600);
    pinMode(trigPin, OUTPUT);
    pinMode(echoPin, INPUT);
    pinMode(buzzerPin, OUTPUT);
    pinMode(motorPin, OUTPUT);
}
                
void loop() {
// Trigger the ultrasonic sensor
    digitalWrite(trigPin, LOW);
    delayMicroseconds(2);
    digitalWrite(trigPin, HIGH);
    delayMicroseconds(10);
    digitalWrite(trigPin, LOW);
                
// Measure the echo duration
long duration = pulseIn(echoPin, HIGH);
                
// Calculate distance in centimeters
int distance = duration * 0.034 / 2;
                
// Output distance to serial monitor
Serial.print("Distance: ");
Serial.println(distance);
                
/* Check if an obstacle is within t
he threshold distance */
if (distance < detectionThreshold) {
/* Turn on the alarm buzzer and 
vibrate the motor */
  digitalWrite(buzzerPin, HIGH);
  digitalWrite(motorPin, HIGH);
} else {
  /* Turn off the alarm buzzer and 
  stop the motor */
  digitalWrite(buzzerPin, LOW);
  digitalWrite(motorPin, LOW);
}   
// Delay for stability
delay(100);
}

Testing and Procedure

Hardware Testing

Figure 6 Hardware Testing

Developer examine the vibration and ultrasonic motors in hardware testing. Though they originally intended to utilize a breadboard, the alarm buzzer module was only powered by 3.5 volts as opposed to 5 volts, and it works.

Figure 7 Hardware Testing

During this particular phase of development, the team of developer conducted rigorous testing on the smart cane. The purpose of these tests was to evaluate how well the device performed when faced with various obstacles or barriers. These barriers could include physical objects or challenging environmental conditions that individuals with visual impairments commonly encounter.

Figure 8 Real-world Scenario Testing

In this phase of development, developer conducted extensive testing on the smart cane, specifically involving individuals with visual impairments. The aim was to assess its functionality in real-world scenarios where users navigate through various barriers. The smart cane was put to the test against different obstacles, and it successfully assisted users in negotiating their surroundings.

Conclusion and Recommended Innovation in 10 years

In conclusion, the TouchGuidance project has demonstrated significant advancements in enhancing accessibility for visually impaired individuals through the development of an Arduino-based smart cane device.The integration of cutting-edge technology has paved the way for a more inclusive and independent experience for users navigating their surroundings. Throughout the past decade, the project has not only addressed the limitations of traditional white canes but has also opened new possibilities for improving the overall quality of life for the visually impaired community.Looking ahead, the future of TouchGuidance relies on continuous innovation to meet the evolving needs of visually impaired individuals. Over the next decade, key areas of improvement include incorporating machine learning for personalized navigation, enhancing sensor technologies for precise obstacle detection, exploring 5G connectivity for a more integrated user experience, and integrating augmented reality for enhanced environmental information.

Prioritizing user experience design, improving battery efficiency, and establishing global accessibility standards through collaboration with international organizations are also crucial. These innovations position TouchGuidance to lead the revolution in accessibility tools, fostering greater independence, safety, and inclusion. Envisioned for the next decade is a fully integrated smart cane system that employs advanced technologies such as artificial intelligence, machine learning, and IoT. The device will not only detect but also identify obstacles, providing detailed descriptions through voice synthesis. It will enable navigation through unfamiliar environments using real-time maps, connect to smart devices for home control, and offer fall detection and emergency response capabilities, significantly enhancing accessibility and instilling confidence in the daily lives of individuals with visual impairments.
